column11: Review Text
It was in the ticket set and they took me, but well, I think I could have passed. It's just amazing to see a statue carved from monolith.

Very large structure. Well maintained. Lots of theories about its authenticity; proven it appears that it is King Parakramabahu. Very interesting top attire and a hidden message there too. Worth a visit.

Although there is no definitive findings about the person of this stature, it is believed to be the statue of the famous King Parakramabahu I who instructed to construct this statue since 12th century. King Parakramabahu I made many contributions during the Polonnaruwa Kingdom with extensive construction of irrigation system that flourished the agricultural activities at that time. His popular sayings was - “No rain water should flow into the sea without being useful to man”. Worth to check this out for quick visit for 5-10 mins especially after the learning about the history of this King.
One of the first sights on our tour of Polonnaruwa, the staute of Parakramabahu I is quite intriguing...as you read the debrief, clarity hits you!

This statue is located near the ruins of polonnaruwa but there is uncertainty as to the identity of this statue.  Some locals say this is the statue of a saint.  The interesting thing is that the colour of the stone of this statue is lighter and not the same colour as the other ruins.  This seem to indicate that this statue is newer but this is just my theory.

The detail here is good still considering its age. You can make our the book it is holding as well as other small details. We started our tour here, and I would suggest it would be an equally good starting place. Definitely have a look while at the archeological site

This is a stone sculpture dating back to the Polonnaruwa period of ancient Sri Lanka This is a world heritage site and a must visit in Polonnaruwa. This is a well preserved site, carved on a large boulder, the statue depicts a majestic figure with a grave expression, holding a book or yoke in his hands.

This is know as potgul vihara statue and it has not recognized it 100% , but traditionally and lot of people believe it is belongs to the great king Parakramabahu (1153 -1186 AD) who made the great lake parakrama samudraya.but these is another view and it is called it is belongs to a sage.actually this is the symbol of polonnaruwa and it is known as a a great exsample of Asian arts.

column8: statue infront of lake with the  monkeys
column11: statue with historical value infront of the parakrama samudraya,it's a giant lake,must visit place in polonnaruwa,there was a site guide and explain us the statue was king,some people believe this is " isiwara"

me and my family members visited the place last year,we spent 1/2 hrs there,we had a guide,and he explained the history related to the statue,sri lankans believe this statue as King parakramabahu I,who made parakrma samudraya seems amazing stone creation,

Another impressive, giant stone statue. One of many I've seen in Sri Lanka. The locals feel great pride with all things Buddha or their ancient history. As with Buddha statues, your back should not be directed towards this statue for photographs.
This statue was hewn from a stone block in situ.  It is huge and impressive.  In recent years it has been protected with a roof but seems to have withstood the weathering of time very well
This is the proud of sri lanka.king parakramabahu made lake called parakrama smudraya.it is most famous plce .
There are arguments about who this statue represents, as well as what he is holding! Nonetheless, an impressive piece of ancient architecture well worth a visit.

An old monolithic statue of Parakramabahu is a living symbol of a dynasty who did a lot for the development of that area. The surrounding of the rock is lush green. Dilapidated monuments of a palace is within its vicinity.  It is worth a visit.
This is a place a person should visit in their lifetime..specially Sri Lankans...Some people say this is the statue of Pulatisi Rishi but some believe that this is the statue of King Parakramabahu

The statue is supposed to that of Parakrambahu ! (although there's no unanimity on this opinion), it dates back to the time of its reign, in the 12th century AD and is considered to be one of the best carvings from the Polonnaruwa period. The image is carved in one huge granite boulder and represents a standing, mustachioed and bearded man, dressed only in what appears to be a dhoti, he wears some kind of cap and both his hands hold what seems to be a palm leaf book. The 3.4m statue is detailed, nicely executed, well preserved and very much worth your time.

An interesting and, sometimes unusually for such treasures, this one is covered to protect it. There are many historic sights in Polonnaruwa and this one could be missed out, but that would be a shame as it is so close and the detail is very good. A mystery too as it is not clear what he is holding.

Incredobly well prserved statue of the ancient king under an awning to protect it fron the elements. It's a lovely statue but Polonnaruwa has far greater treasures if I'm honest. Still well worth a look if you are visiting the incredible ancient library on the same plot. It depicts the bearded king reading from a palm leaf book and to be fair if it was anywhere else other than the wonder studded Polonnaruwa it would be the main attraction I'm sure!
They are trying to protect this fine statue carved from solid rock. It is certainly worth searching around the site to find it.
Anywhere else this hugely historic and beautiful statue would be a "main attraction' . Here its a bit upstaged by all the other historic relics but you should not miss it

This is a statue of King Parakramabahu carved into a large stone block that sits south of the main Pollonaruwa complex. The carving is in very good condition and is interesting as it has a large beard and moustache, the King is reading for a "palm leaf book" and there is s small carving of a rabbit on his left shoulder!! Really cool and makes the effort to get here worth it!

Polonnaruwa tour started here. It takes about five minutes to complete the visit to this site. We did not know the significance of the statue, as we were on drive around arrangement, without the guide and explanations.
This very large statue is off by itself near the entrance. A short walk to see it, but worth  the trek.

It's only 10 mins walk along the lake bank from the museum. King parakramabahu is one of the most influential figures from his time. He lead to the development of the polonnaruwa district and the entire north Central. The statue is not huge. But if you are in polonnaruwa do check it out. And tickets are not checked here. So even without a ticket you can visit the statue of parakramabahu
The importance of this site is about the statue that it holds. The statue is of King Prakramabahu holding a book. See this one to feel the history behind all of Polonnaruwa.

It's an interesting statue - always good to an escape from all the buddhas - and I like how it's cut out of the backing frame.  There's not really much in this southern group of ruins but it's a good excuse to ride along the Bund south from the museum and enjoy the lake views.

A visit through Polonnaruwa ruins would not be complete without visiting the Statue of Parakeamabahu I.  This King was not Buddhist however he was responsible for the man made lake near his statute and a lot of good things he did for the people.  His name is spoken of and heard throughout Sri Lanka/history. Everyone should be respectful for the dress code they don’t offer sarongs so best to take one yourself, and remove your hat.  Would visit again and recommend to others.
Nothing too fancy or interesting, just a big statue. According to the commentary plague by the side, scholars apparently aren’t sure if it was the king or just a sage.
This is the statue of the famous old king here.He made the man made lake here. Worth the visit.You need about half an hour here.

Parakraman Bahu  sculptor is of great talent and it is the first time in Sri Lankan history of Thibanga style (the statue bend from 3 places) came to statues during the great king Parakramabahu's era. The statue has nore than 2500 years of history and and this stone statue is located close to Parakrama Samudraya (meaning like sea made from joining 3 large tanks) and this location is known as the Pothgul Vehera.(A library) .It is a great creation of Sri Lankan  history. This is an excellent place for a visit. The history of this place never ends and has a lot to obtain. Even though it is named as the statue of the  King Parakramabahu there are a lot of different stories as to who actually the statute represents. Some says it is King Parakramabahu the Great some others others say that is of Agastaya from another sage from a different era. Archeological Departmernt says that this statue is not the king & it is sage Pulasthi's statue. because the object held in the hand represent a palm-leaf manuscript of a sage. But it is widely believed that this is the statue (carved out of Rock) of an ancient great King Parakramabahu. The king believed to be the one of the greatest in Sri Lankan history during which period it was self-sufficient in food due to agricultural and prosperity in all other sectors concerned. The vast lake, Parakrama Samudraya in front of the statue has been built by this king to retain the water for agriculture and other uses. The area got dry for 9 months of the year and it’s a remarkable planning of storage of water to supply for cultivations throughout the year. There is a school of thought that this statue of King Parakramabahu is of a great scholar at that time. There is a beautiful wildness on the outskirts of the forest and it is easy to get to along the bund of the Parakrama Samudraya.  It has easy parking across  where elephants are often seen. It is better to visit as early to avoid sun heat. Photos taken posing back to the statue of the King is prohibited and there are security to enforce it. This statue looks at Potgul Vehera (Library) and there is a chronicles saying that this library was built by King Parakramabahu, to protect his knowledge to future. Therefore he looks at the library built by him where his knowledge is contained. But some of folk traditions saying greater king Parakramabahu didn't make his own statues. This statue looks big at the guide books, but up close, it's both huge and amazingly and well preserved. When you hire a guide from near the museum, sometimes they  avoid this statue to save some time. Don't miss it.
This face of king parakamabahu. He is good and fare king of those days. He is the founder of the paraka samudaya big tank.
A rather ordinary Statue of a standing Buddha. Generally very ordinary facial and hand features. Nothing much
The statue is easily reached and signposted. About 5 minutes will cover it. We spent longer at the lake watching the elephant graze by the water.

This is the most attractive and well known place of Polonnaruwa. It can be reached by 1.5km drive along the bund of Parakrama Samudrya. This might be the statue of King Parakramabahu Great or Indian high priest called Kapila/ Pulasthi . It is used as the symbol of Polonnaruwa.
Yet another fantastic ancient Buddhist statue of incredible skill & antiquity.  One of many sites we visited with our driver on a culture packed tour of Sri Lanka.

This place is situated out side of the ancient city of Polonnaruwa.Therefore you might miss this place. It is near the parakrama  samudraya( big reservoir in Polonaruwa).If you visit during evening it would be amazing moment to feel the calm and quiet.
Standing on its own and happily complete this statue is well worth a view. There seems to be some debate as to whether this statue represents a King or a Sage but I guess we'll never know for sure
It's not sure that it is really the statue of the great king Parakramabahu I - it's maybe a statue of a sage man... But, it's worth the visit if you are in the area of the lakeside at sunset...
It was our last stop, nice bicycle ride near the lake. The place was empty and it was a good place to take pictures.
This statue is one of those archeology relics that is worth seeing. But it is not one if the SL standouts.  Add thus if you have the time.
Situated close to Parakrama samudraya. One has to know the background history and visit. If not this might not look amazing or attractive.
It is situated in the vicinity of the other cultural sites. Another magnificent piece of sculpture and history.
A rock carved king's statue, on the southern part of Polonnaruwa ruins, not so much interesting as the rest of the site.
This stone statue is a brilliant representation of an ancient Buddhist king. Alongside is a statue of the reclining Buddha as well as a seated figure

This statue is tucked away in the southern Ruins, about 1 km south aong the levy of the reservoir, withinthe "Southern Ruins" , largely a Budhist Monastery and this beautifull statue. A bit out of the way but free of charge.

If timescales are short, recommend at least seeing Statue of Parakramabahu and reservoir and less cost. Was able to take interesting photos of statue and reservoir as less busy than main Polonnaruwa ancient city.
As a tourist you need to read about the history and the meaning of sites yo are visiting. I wanted to see the statue after reading about the king, I appreciated more.
It's amongst lots of ancient sites in this magnificent ancient city and thanks UNESCO for keeping them safe. Get a guide to explain the history or visit the museum first, adding to the enjoyment.
If you are a person who values history and culture of a country, this is a must visit place. You also sure find other places of interest around this area such as ruins and nature
Arrived here saw this then back in car...wasnt much at this site and could have missed...set scene for rest of area and why created

This is the statue of the king who made Polonnaruwa a special place in Sri Lanka. I did not remember the ceiling over the statue from my previous visits, but our guide pointed out that one Buddha statue fell apart due to weather conditions and that motivated the authorities to do some covering of important statues. This is a statue that is a must-see when visiting the sacred ruins.

I started my exploration of Polonnaruwa from this site.It's an unusual statue and also subject of dispute.Some say it's a figure of Indian Vedic Rishi Agastya and some say it's statue of King Parakramaprabhu I. Whatever the debate, it's an image in total contrast to what generally seen in Buddhist archeological ruins.
Situated near the man made lake !!!! As per locals they have joined multiple lakes to form a single one . Nice to see still its standing high !!!

In the blazing heat of August an intrepid traveller can brave the noonday sun with plenty of sunscreen and water to take in these monumental carvings of Buddha. Four separate postures you are required to remove your shoes and hat. Late afternoon is best as the sun exposure in this part of the world is extreme.

Located closer to Hotel Suduaraliya,near Parakrana Samudraya. The place is well kept with several ancient ruins of the same era in the vicinity.It's a marvelous creation by ancient craftsmen.Happy to see it in good shape even after so many challenges in the history,including weather.
The stone sculpture that is believed to be of the great king of Sri lanka King Parakramabahu is a monument that should never be missed.

The statue of King Parakramabahu 1. Easy access to access to statue and some of the ruin of Stupa and a building believe to be a library. Parakrama Samudhaya (Lake) just walking distance from this statue.

This statue is part of the expanse of polonnaruwa and is a very well preserved example of stonework. The King that is represented here dos a lot of development work and construction. He is shown standing with something in his hand that resembles a book. Perhaps to represent how knowledgeable he was.

This is the statue of the King Maha Parakramabahy 1 built right next to "Parakrama Samudraya" (Parakrama Ocean). The king Parackramabahu built this huge lake for irrigation to supply water to cultivation. As a mark of respect to this master piece, the statue of this great king is here still overlooking the lake.
Very impressive statue of Parakramabahu 1 who have built the Parakrama Samudra Reservoir , this can be seen free of charge as it's out of the site .
Impressively large but there is no curation to set it in context or give more detailed information .
After other sites this one was different. Shoes off for close up but pretty special. Further away from other sites to visit.

Like most of the historical sites in ancient Polonnaruwa this was different and quite spectacular. There are a number of statues craved into the large granite rock. it is necessary to remove footwear when visiting this area.

King Parakramabahu statue is something that you should see. It has nothing to do with Buddhism, but the work this King has done for public, and the Buddhism was amazing. You will hear this great king’s name everywhere you visit. He should be respected yesterday, today and for ever.
This is in the south of the old town and a way away, so be prepared for a cycle or an extra Rickshaw fare.

This 4 metre high statue is quite unlike anything else we saw in either Polonnaruwa or Anuradhapura. It's a shame historians can't agree who it represents! Certainly worth a quick photo stop and in our opinion - better than Potgul Vihara which is a couple of hundred metres away.

As has been said by many others before this is a great historical site and one at which you can get ample information to give you the background to the ruins. If you like history you should go, if you don't like history you should still go just in case this is what spurs you to become interested in the rise and fall of civilisations.

Kind of like a start point for what you are about to encounter - would not include after some of the grander sites - but interesting none the less as it is an example of a royal personage rather than a buddha as a statue.

This stature situated on the very edge of Parakrama Samudra (Sea of King Parakramabahu ) the huge artificial lake created by the king, is said to the statue of the great King , Parakramabahu the first. But later on doubts was raised as to this fact and some say it's the statute of sage Pulasthi. It's a beautiful statue of the king and the its as depicted he is looking at the great lake. It does inspire kind of awe and at the same time as feeling of tranquillity at this site if you visit it during late afternoon or  just after sunrise.
These are interesting carvings of Buddha in various poses. The walk down through the park is also interesting. There is some restoration going on but the statues are are still easy to admire.

Good site to visit. Do not miss the houses this kiNg built for the Buddhist monks to study and the library. These are found in the Grounds of this  site to the right to the. King's relief  sculpture. The man made lake this king  had planned is across the road of this site.
very nice to see, we saw this at very beginning, however, if you skip this one nothing will happen. if you running late and are in hurry, this is ok to skip.
This is the first thing that we saw in Polonnaruwa. This was a huge statue carved out of stone. However, apart from that there isn't much to see in it!!

Forgive the scepticism, but nothing about this statue said 'original', not least the fact that nobody seems clear about who this statue actually is . . . I'd say you can give this one a miss if you are time-poor in Polonnaruwa.

this is controversial  opinion disclosed by the historians then same are saying this is parakkramabahu statue but others said thi is pulasthirishi(like spiritual person)any way commonly believed this is king parakkramabahu statue.it has been made out of granite natural rock .his hand on the olaleaves book and very well  proportionated statue and he was in sri lanka 11 century AD.

Our driver/guide proudly took us to see this large statue located beside a reservoir during a private tour of Sri Lanka. What does one say other than it is a large statue of a king that has stood in remarkable condition since the 12th Century? There is nothing else here. I wouldn't go out of my way to visit, but if in the vicinity, I am certain many of you might enjoy it.

amazing to see such a large statue carved out of stone... and still in quite good condition. however, there isn't much to it other than the argument of whether he was a sage or a king. short stop, but a good one..

One of the places that pretty much most people will visit. The identity of the statue is a incognita, in which some say is the king Parakramabahu and other does not believe it to be. The statue is magnificent.

This is situated at near the Potgul Vehera in Polonnaruwa, This statue made from huge rock. It is amazing development of ancients. It will take huge effort to develop this sort of statue with today's technology. It's truly wonderful.
Disputed whether it is a king or a sage.....nice carving.....not hard to approach...close to the Parakrama Samudraya tank......take a photo and move on.

This is not the statue of Parakramabaahu the Great as lot of people like to say but the statue of Pulasthi Rishi.The object held in the hands of the statue may be an ola (cured palm leaves) book  and the fact that it is located close to the Pothgul (Poth = Books, Gula = Hall or room) Vehera, which was a library in ancient times and slso facing that direction, supports this theory. Pulasthi is the Great grand father of Most powerful ancient Sri lankan king Rawana. Same like face is carved on a rock on the Ella – Wellawaya road. It is visible from the main road. Gettng closer is not safe as the surroundings are full of wasps. This statue is 11'-2" tall and situated on the eastern bank of our Greatest tank Parakrama samudraya (Sea). It has been built during Pollonnaruwa era of 12th Centuary.

My guide described this statue as a sage figure in the Lanka beliefs and it was the very first thing I saw at Polonnaruwa.  It is very impressive and they are doing their best to preserve it for future generations.  Definitely worth a stop....

It is widely believed that this is the statue (carved out of Rock) of an ancient great King Parakramabahu.. The king believed to be the one of the greatest in Sri Lankan history during which period it was self-sufficient in food due to agricultural and prosperity of all other concern. The vast lake in front of the statue has been built by this king to retain the water for agriculture and other uses. The area being dry for 9months of the year it’s a remarkable planning. There is school of thoughts that this statue is that of a great scholar at that time who was call pander Pualathisi
This is a beautiful and very old statue which a local told me is sometimes thought of as the king eating a slice of papaya...
Beautiful wildness on the outskirts of the forest  easy to get to. Part of the whole polunawara ruins. Located with easy parking across from a lake where elephants are often seen.
This statue looks big I the guide books, but up close, it's both huge and amazingly well preserved. The surrounding temple is I need of some repair, though.
Now the place is much better organized than previous visits, Better to visit as early to avoid sun heat.

I would have liked to be able to take a picture with the guy since we sorta look alike, but they don't allow pictures with back to the King. Read up on him on wiki, sounds like he did good by his people.
So far it's ok! but you need to be aware of those people who pretend to be a tour guide but actually they are not. They are just cheating your money.

This statue is identified as greater king parakrambahu, but some of Archaeologists saying this is a statue of Pulasthi, a sage who was in Sri Lanka. This statue looking at Potgul Vehera (Library). chronicles saying this library was build by King Parakramabahu, to protect his knowledge to future & he is looking at the library. But some of folk traditions saying greater king parakramabahu didn't make his own statues & this statue is not the king & it is sage pulasthi's statue. because the object held in the hand represent a palm-leaf manuscript of a sage. when you hire a guide from near the museum, some times they are escaping this statue to save some time. don't miss it
This is a just a small statue of king Parakramabahu. I won't say it's a must-see attraction. This can be entirely skipped.
This is an excellent place for a visit. The history of this place never ends and has alot to obtain. Must visit place in Polonnaruwa. More than 2500 years of history.

It really is a marvelous sculpture but  lacks any symbolization or association around to make the statue look Majestic as the so powerful, great King Parakramabahu, who without doubt was one of the most honored in Sri lankan history. worst is the shed built to shade this precious statue. It is a real shame.

a lot of different stories as to who actually the statute represents. some says it King Parakramabahu the Great, others say it is Agastaya, other another sage from a different era. for me, i believe it is King Parakramabahu. a truly wonderful piece of art. may it stand till the end of days.
again i can tell u the sculptors tallent n first time in sri lankan history thibanga style(the statue bend from 3 places)came to statues during the great king parakramabahu's era.

This stone Statue is located close to parakrama samudraya and this location is known by Pothgul Vehera.(A library) .there are lot of believes of this statue.what ever it is ,it is a great creation of our history.
Actually this not the statue of king Parakramabahu, It is the statue of a powerful sage Pulastya rishi (son of Brahma), one of the beautiful statue you should see.

Its identity is a mystery. Some say it is the statue of King Parakramabahu and others say it is a sage The statue has a grave expression and seems to be holding an old manuscript. The statue is a little away from where the other ancient ruins are.
